misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the method `sc.next()` will capture a full name or record (like 'Alice Smith') as a single entry in the names array.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java's Scanner notional machine, `next()` delimits tokens by any whitespace (space, tab, or newline). If a user enters a first and last name, they will be split into two separate array elements, causing the subsequent scores to be read into the wrong array or causing an InputMismatchException.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the number of students N provided by the user will always be at least 1, ensuring that the index N - 1 is always valid for accessing the 'highest' student.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student assumes the problem space guarantees a non-empty set. In the Java execution model, an array can have a length of 0 if N is 0. Accessing `names[N - 1]` in this state (index -1) results in a runtime crash rather than a graceful handling of an empty leaderboard.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the input stream must be partitioned into entire arrays (all names first, then all scores) to match the internal storage structure of the program.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student views the input process as 'filling' a memory block entirely before moving to the next block. This prevents the program from being able to process data in a record-oriented format (e.g., Alice 85, Bob 92), which is more natural for data entry, because the Scanner notional machine is locked into the first loop until N tokens are consumed.

evidence.code_snippet: for (int i = 0; i < N; i++) { names[i] = sc.next(); }
for (int i = 0; i < N; i++) { scores_array[i] = sc.nextInt(); }

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sc.next() will capture a full 'name' as a single String entry, even if the name provided by the user contains spaces (e.g., 'Alice Smith').
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In the Java Scanner notional machine, next() is a token-based method that treats any whitespace (space, tab, newline) as a delimiter. It does not read a semantic 'line' of text but rather the next contiguous sequence of non-whitespace characters.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: runtime exception (InputMismatchException) or logical data misalignment if input contains spaces.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the value of N will always be at least 1, making the calculation N-1 a safe index for array access.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to account for the edge case of an empty collection (N=0). In the Java memory model, an array of size 0 is valid, but accessing index -1 (0-1) results in a memory access violation.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the relationship between a name and a score is only maintained through simultaneous, identical index manipulations across two separate memory structures.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: While this is a valid implementation of parallel arrays, it demonstrates a lack of understanding of Object-Oriented encapsulation where data (String name) and its attributes (int score) are bound together as a single object (Student) in the mental model.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: complex maintenance and potential for logic errors if one swap is forgotten.
